awd_titl_txt: Developing the Skill and Will to Succeed in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
The School of Life Sciences at the University of Nevada Las Vegas is implementing a new program entitled "Developing the Skill and Will to Succeed in STEM." This program provides three years of scholarship support to a total of 25 academically talented undergraduate biology majors with documented financial need. A primary goal is to diversify and increase the number of students entering STEM professions. In addition to scholarship support, a number of curricular and co-curricular enhancements will be put into effect to increase achievement and career readiness of program participants.

The introductory biology lecture series will be enriched by inclusion of active learning experiences that will promote student engagement and persistence for all biology majors. A prediction model that analyzes student use of digital learning resources will also be incorporated into the introductory courses. This model will facilitate early identification of students at-risk to earn poor course grades, allowing redirection towards more effective learning strategies. Scholarship recipients will attend a STEM career seminar series and will participate in pursuing undergraduate research and STEM internship opportunities.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Developing the Skill and Will to Succeed in STEM program provided over $420,000 in scholarship support to 36 academically talented undergraduate students. The program strategically promoted the academic success of scholarship recipients through incorporation of research-based practices. Compared to the broader population of biology majors, Succeed in STEM scholars remained biology majors at higher rates, graduated at higher rates, and graduated in less time.

Career readiness and professional identity of Succeed in STEM scholars were cultivated through peer and faculty mentoring, professional development workshops, and career exploration panels. Scholars regularly met with the program faculty and with peer mentors to discuss their academic and social experiences on campus. Professional development workshops covered topics such as effective study strategies, time management techniques, creating a professional online presence, developing a professional network, writing a resume/CV and cover letter, professionalism during interviews, stress management strategies and mental health resources, applying to graduate/professional school, and finding research and internship opportunities. Career exploration panels featured diverse professionals working in a range of biology-related fields including public health and forensic laboratories, engineering and scientific consulting, national park resource management, science education research, biotechnology research, genetic counseling, and scientists working for a variety of agencies (Clark County Wetlands Park, Southern Nevada Water Authority, Nevada Department of Wildlife, United States Geological Survey, United States Department of Energy).

The quality of the educational environment was improved through the complete redesign of the two-semester introductory biology course series, which is required of biology majors at the University of Nevada Las Vegas (UNLV). The two redesigned courses now richly incorporate research-based instructional practices including active learning, self-testing, spaced study, formative assessment with feedback, and collaborative learning. During the period of the award, over 7,000 students enrolled into the redesigned courses, and the predicted enrollment for both courses is 1,600 to 1,800 students each year.


Last Modified: 10/17/2024
Modified by: Jenifer C Utz
